title: Remove the 'Keep' button in Chat Agent mode and use standard save behavior

labels.name: ux
labels.description: User experience issues

body:
In agent mode, after the agent modifies a file, the current user experience presents a confusing "in-between" state. The file can be saved, but it is not "kept" until the user explicitly clicks the "Keep" button. This results in several unintuitive behaviors:
- Files can be deleted by the user, but if the user clicks "Undo" after the file is deleted but not "kept", the file can reappear.
- It is unclear to the user whether changes are permanent or not, and the distinction between "save" and "keep" is not obvious or necessary.

#### Proposal
Remove the "Keep" button and the associated intermediate state in agent mode. Instead, when the agent modifies files, the modifications should be handled as normal file edits within VS Code. Saving (or auto-save) should work as it does with any file, respecting the user's configured settings for saving. There should not be a separate "keep"/"undo" state after agent edits—just standard save/undo as with any other manual edit.

title: Incorrect Information regarding "Free 30 day Copilot Use"
body:
Type: Bug

Summary: Copilot trial immediately charges $10 instead of providing the advertised free 30-day trial

Description:
When attempting to start the GitHub Copilot Chat free trial in VS Code, the extension indicates that I should receive 30 days free and be billed one month later. However, instead of activating a trial, my account is charged $10 immediately.

This behavior is misleading, as it prevents me from actually trying the free trial period before being billed. I would love to evaluate Copilot Chat during the advertised trial period to see how it integrates with my workflow and contributes to GitHub research, but the current behavior makes that impossible.

Extension Version: 0.30.1
VS Code Version: Code 1.103.1 (Universal) (360a4e4fd251bfce169a4ddf857c7d25d1ad40da, 2025-08-12T16:25:40.542Z)
OS Version: Darwin arm64 24.6.0

Steps to Reproduce:
	1.	Open VS Code and install/enable GitHub Copilot extension.
	2.	Attempt to start the free trial via the subscription prompt.
	3.	Observe that the subscription charges $10 immediately instead of deferring billing by 30 days.

Expected Behavior:
A full 30-day trial period should activate without immediate billing, with the first $10 charge occurring only after the trial ends.

Actual Behavior:
The account is charged $10 immediately, canceling the trial opportunity.

<!-- 🔧 Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes

<!-- 🪓 If you answered No above, use 'Help: Start Extension Bisect' from Command Palette to try to identify the cause. -->
<!-- 📣 Issues caused by an extension need to be reported directly to the extension publisher. The 'Help > Report Issue' dialog can assist with this. -->
- VS Code Version: 1.103.1, microsoft/vscode@360a4e4fd251bfce169a4ddf857c7d25d1ad40da, x64
- OS Version: Fedora Workstation 41, 6.15.9-101.fc41.x86_64

I edited the version so that the bot properly labels the issue.

#### Steps to Reproduce:
1. Input a phrase in the `Search` tab. Press Enter.
2. Switch applications.
3. Switch back to VSC.

---

It's worth noting a few things here:
* Following those steps allowed me to reproduce the issue consistently a few times right now. However, in my experience, the scenario doesn't always lead to the bug. Maybe it depends on the revision of the application or some broader context.
* The issue manifests even without switching applications. However, I haven't been able to reproduce it at will that way.
* The same issue manifests in the `References` tab used by clangd (clangd version 19.1.7 (Fedora 19.1.7-4.fc41)).

I haven't been able to spot the bug with `--verbose --log=debug`, so I don't have any logs to share at the moment.

The problem has been present at least in the past few versions of the editor.

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create a demo repo
2. Create .github/copilot-instructions.md with contain of 
```
#user name
Always call the user Ashley in every response, no matter what
```
3. Ask copilot agent "Who am I?" and "What should you call me?"
4. Get result being called as "user" or "VSCode user" 

P/S: I try to attach screenshot of the setup but failed to upload it
P/S 2: I try to investigate the situation and my result that copilot does not seem to recognize .github folder entirely. It do recognize the folder if I tell it to do so. It can read .github/copilot-instructions.md if I tell it to do so. I asked why it did not read it in the first place, it keep apologize without giving any better response.

title: replace_string_in_file has an error in a path containing spaces
body: Hello, this question has been bothering me for a long time [here](https://github.com/orgs/community/discussions/168225#discussioncomment-13966365) and I finally found the answer. Because the folder or file path contains spaces, the code cannot be generated directly using the agent chat method. Instead, the code can only be modified through the terminal. This issue was mentioned in [#256867](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/256867) but havent solved. By removing the spaces, I found that it works! Therefore, the replace_string_in_file tool needs to be modified to adapt to the space problem in the path!

title: Updates common for use in vscode-copilot-chat
Ctrl+C not working to end a process in external cmd.exe terminal

labels.name: terminal-process
labels.description: Problems launching processes, managing ptys, exiting, process leaks, etc.

body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! bug_report_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- 🕮 Read our guide about submitting issues: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/wiki/Submitting-Bugs-and-Suggestions -->
<!-- 🔎 Search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->
<!-- 🧪 Test using the latest Insiders build to see if your issue has already been fixed: https://code.visualstudio.com/insiders/ -->
<!-- 💡 Instead of creating your report here, use 'Report Issue' from the 'Help' menu in VS Code to pre-fill useful information. -->
<!-- 🔧 Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes

<!-- 🪓 If you answered No above, use 'Help: Start Extension Bisect' from Command Palette to try to identify the cause. -->
<!-- 📣 Issues caused by an extension need to be reported directly to the extension publisher. The 'Help > Report Issue' dialog can assist with this. -->
- VS Code Version: 1.103.1
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open an external command prompt
2. Run some process
3. Hit Ctrl+C

I can end the process using Ctrl+Fn+S just fine, but this is an annoying and unintuitive key combo to press. It also doesn't work using a bog standard fullsize external keyboard, so we don't have to blame the keyboard or its firmware.

Some observations:

* Pressing Ctrl+C before running a process cancels the typed in command and produce a new line with a fresh prompt.
* Pressing Ctrl+C does not display `^C`.
* Pressing Ctrl+Fn+S *does* display a `^C` and the terminate batch question, just as if Ctrl+C was pressed.
* My cmd.exe options are all default.
* The options pertaining to starting an external terminal in VScode are all default.

This has been reported a few times, mostly around 2017, so I'm not sure why this pops up again. Those issues seem to get closed unjustly, might I add, because clearly to me, the problem still exists. In some of those issues, it has also been said that it might be fixable by setting `terminal.external.windowsExec` to `C:\WINDOWS\Sysnative\cmd.exe`. I don't know what this is, it doesn't exist. Just wanted to get that out there as well.

The most important thing to mention here:

* This problem doesn't occur when starting a command prompt "normally", e.g. by starting it from Start->Run. It seems *any* method other than starting it vrom VScode, doesn't have this problem. In other words, **this problem is exclusive to VScode**.

I should also mention that on my previous computer, I had this fixed, although I don't remember how. This is an issue that seems notoriously difficult to track down a solution for, because there are so many terminals, OS'es, different programs responding different, environments, and other non-related problems.

title: Treat ellipsis character as search wildcard
body: Some tools, like the Playwright test runner CLI, ellipsize filenames with the `…` character: At the moment, the ellipsized path isn't clickable because VS Code's fuzzy matching doesn't handle that character well. This PR adds `…` as an alternative wildcard. This makes both the terminal path matching and the file quick picker find the file.

title: Copilot Chat unable to create files in Agent Mode in WSL2

labels.name: info-needed
labels.description: Issue requires more information from poster

body:
![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/ffb0e7bd-b319-40ee-bbb0-dd11db6ba66e)

- Copilot Chat Extension Version: 0.30.1
- GitHub Copilot Extension Version: 1.350.0
- VS Code Version: 1.103.1
- OS Version: Windows 11 Pro 24H2 (build : 26100.4946
- Feature : agent mode 
- Selected model : GPT 4.1
- Logs: [copilot_chat_file_create_issue.txt](https://github.com/user-attachments/files/21887631/copilot_chat_file_create_issue.txt)


Steps to Reproduce:

1. Install VSCode , GitHub Copilot extension , GitHub Copilot Chat extension, WSL extension . 
2. add the below to User settings.json in VS code . 
`    "remote.extensionKind": {
        "GitHub.copilot": ["ui"],
        "GitHub.copilot-chat": ["ui"]
    },`
3. Connect to a WSL2 backend example : Ubuntu 24.04 LTS
4. Make sure the extensions are running in VS code locally and not running in remote WSL . 
5. VS Code File > Open Folder>  Select any folder that is inside WSL2 filesystem.
6. Open Copilot chat  in agent mode and select GPT 4.1.
7. type "create a hello world program in python "
8. all the tool calls to create file will fail with the  the below error . 

```
I am unable to create the Python file because the workspace path is restricted. Please let me know the correct absolute path within your workspace where you want the hello_world.py file to be created.

```

7. I'm corporate environment , so unable to run the copilot extensions remotely inside WSL as the proxy, vpn etc doesn't play well with WSL2   . I need to run it locally in VS Code using "UI" mode , but UI mode is unable to edit any files inside WSL . so unable to use copilot for more than a week .
8. I was able to replicate the same issue in my personal PC as well . so it is not a corporate access or firewall issue .

title: Copilot's local Workspace Index forever stays in "Updating local workscape index..." when using WSL Remote
body:
**VS Code:**
Version: 1.103.1 (user setup)
OS: Windows_NT x64 10.0.26100

**Github Copilot Extension** 
Version 1.350.0

**WSL2**
Distro: Ubuntu 24.04

**Issue:**
Having a non Github repo, so no remote index possible.

The locale workspace indexing works perfectly fine when having my repo sitting in the Windows filesystem and opening it in VS Code. The codebase indexing is done within seconds after it's started.

But when having the repo sitting in the WSL 2 distros ext4 filesystem and opening VS Code via "code ." from WSL2 terminal, starting the local workspace index stays in the "Updating local workspace index..." forever. (Beside that issue, the WSL2 repo setup is working fine for me since years, so it's not a general config issue with VS Code or WSL setup I think)

title: Investigate delay when creating webviews

labels.name: webview
labels.description: Webview issues

body:
While exploring webview performance, I noticed that there appears to be a persistent 500ms delay between the webview iframe being created and added to the Dom, and the script inside of the webview ([`index.html`](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/blob/main/src/vs/workbench/contrib/webview/browser/pre/index.html)) actually starting

The network tab shows that `index.html` loads in ~10ms, so it is not clear what exactly is causing the delay

Here are the verbose logs. `webview/mounted` is when the iframe is added into the dom. `scriptstart` is when the script is run:

<details>


Notice the ~2 second gap between the `cpu_info.cc ` event and the next event. Profiles in the window show that nothing is happening during this time 

So far I've tried to reproduce this in Chrome with normal iframes and in electron using a custom protocol for the iframe. In both cases the iframe loads very quickly so I'm unsure what is causing this delay for VS Code


@deepak1556 Any ideas or additional electron/chromium logs I can try collecting?

title: Terminal issue in VS Code .snap build (PTY host unresponsive)
body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! bug_report_template ⚠️⚠️ -->  
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->  
<!-- 🕮 Read our guide about submitting issues: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/wiki/Submitting-Bugs-and-Suggestions -->  
<!-- 🔎 Search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->  
<!-- 🧪 Test using the latest Insiders build to see if your issue has already been fixed: https://code.visualstudio.com/insiders/ -->  
<!-- 💡 Instead of creating your report here, use 'Report Issue' from the 'Help' menu in VS Code to pre-fill useful information. -->  
<!-- 🔧 Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->  
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: **Yes**  

- **VS Code Version:** 1.103.1 (built from source)  
- **OS Version:** Ubuntu 22.04 LTS, Ubuntu 24.04 LTS  

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Build the Snap package from VS Code source using Gulp (`vscode-linux-x64-build-snap`).  
2. Install the generated `.snap` file.  
3. Open VS Code and try to launch the integrated terminal.  

### Actual Behavior  
The integrated terminal does not open and shows the error:  

```  
PTY host unresponsive  
```  

### Expected Behavior  
The integrated terminal should work inside the Snap build (just like it does in the `.deb` build).  

### Additional Information  
- Initially, the snap build failed due to missing `patchelf`. After adding `patchelf`, the build succeeded.  
- The issue only occurs in the **Snap build**. The **.deb package build works correctly**, and the terminal functions as expected.  
- Tried changing the Snap base from `core20` → `core22`. With `core22`, the terminal works, but the Snap only opens in Ubuntu 22.04, not in Ubuntu 24.04.

title: Copilot tool `copilot_listCodeUsages`/`#usages` is essentially broken (with fix)

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issue identified by VS Code Team member as probable bug

body:
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates -->
<!-- Please attach logs to help us diagnose your issue -->

- Copilot Chat Extension Version: (latest built from code)
Version: 1.104.0-insider (system setup)
Commit: 5d24d0fea3ffc65b824989dda916714a46ca97a7
Date: 2025-08-19T05:03:18.690Z
Electron: 37.2.3
ElectronBuildId: 12035395
Chromium: 138.0.7204.100
Node.js: 22.17.0
V8: 13.8.500258-electron.0
OS: Windows_NT x64 10.0.26100

I noticed that the "#usages" tool usually doesn't work, almost always outputting "Symbol XYZ cannot be found" in chat (an apparent "error").  Similarly, leveraging the Language Model APIs directly, scenarios that involve the AI choosing `copilot_listCodeUsages` don't seem to work.

I tracked this down to the implementation in `usagesTool.tsx`.  It looks like, if a file path is specified (which would be by default in Copilot Chat, when there is an active file, and also seems to be the case when AI leverages the tool), it does a `getDocumentSymbol` (i.e. the 'outline' symbols).  Upon not finding a match (and there are several reasons why no match would be found), and since `getDefinitions`/`getReferences`/`getImplementations` requires an actual location to look up, it gives up.

A potential fix (which I've applied myself and seems to work well) is for `GetUsagesTool` to fall back to `getWorkspaceSymbols` (which it would have used if no file had been specified) and then retry `getDocumentSymbols` with those additional paths.  With that fix, the tool seems to be functioning as expected, and leveraging the C++ language service for `getDefinitions`/`getReferences`/`getImplementations`.

title: Allow dialogs in automation

This also switches to using the custom dialog in electron so that the driver can interact with it.

title: fix checkpoints not working in editor instance
Find Widget Lock
body: Type: Feature Request It would be really helpful to have an option to prevent the Find Widget from closing when pressing the Escape key. Here's the issue: When using the Find in Selection feature along with Select Next Occurrence during coding, we often press Escape to remove the cursors. However, pressing Escape also closes the Find Widget. This forces us to reselect the code and re-enable Find in Selection, which disrupts the workflow. An option to lock the Find Widget open — or to separate the Escape behavior (e.g., one press to remove cursors, a second to close the widget) — would make the experience better. title: MCP tools missing in GH Copilot agent context

labels.name: info-needed
labels.description: Issue requires more information from poster

body:
We **THINK** we have determined this is a systemic issue with the MCP extension → GitHub Copilot agent integration layer, NOT a configuration problem.

Evidence of Systemic Failure:

Universal Tool Absence: 0 out of 23 MCP tools visible in agent context
Multiple Server Types Affected: Node.js, Python, and uvx servers all fail equally
Configuration Proven Correct: Firebase MCP server works perfectly when tested manually
Consistent Failure Pattern: No partial success across any MCP implementation
Technical Assessment:

MCP Servers: ✅ Functional and operational
Configurations: ✅ Syntactically correct and validated
Authentication: ✅ Resolved and working
MCP Extension: ❌ Not bridging tools to Copilot agent context
Integration Layer: ❌ Fundamental failure in MCP-to-Copilot bridge

🔄 STEPS TO REPRODUCE
Prerequisites:
Windows 11 with VS Code latest version
GitHub Copilot extensions installed (github.copilot + github.copilot-chat)
MCP extension installed (automatalabs.copilot-mcp@0.0.68)
Node.js, Python, and uvx available in PATH
Reproduction Steps:
Step 1: Configure Multiple MCP Servers

// Create .vscode/mcp.json with multiple server types
{"mcpServers": {"firebase": {"command": "node","args": ["path/to/firebase-mcp-server/dist/stdio.js"],"env": {"FIREBASE_PROJECT_ID": "your-project"},"tools": ["firebase-auth-list-users", "firestore-list-collections"]},"fetch": {"command": "uvx","args": ["mcp-server-fetch"],"tools": ["fetch"]}}}
Step 2: Verify MCP Servers Work Manually

# Test Firebase MCP server directly
$env:FIREBASE_PROJECT_ID="your-project"
node path/to/firebase-mcp-server/dist/stdio.js

# Test Fetch MCP server directly  
uvx mcp-server-fetch
Step 3: Restart VS Code Completely

Close all VS Code instances
Reopen VS Code in workspace with MCP configuration
Wait for all extensions to load
Step 4: Open GitHub Copilot Agent Session

Open any file in workspace
Start new GitHub Copilot agent conversation
Request agent to list all available tools
Expected Result:
Agent should show ALL MCP tools alongside standard VS Code tools:

firebase-auth-list-users, firestore-list-collections (Firebase MCP)
fetch (Fetch MCP)
create_file, read_file, run_in_terminal, etc. (Standard tools)
Actual Result:
Agent ONLY shows standard VS Code tools:

create_file, read_file, run_in_terminal, etc. ✅
NO MCP tools visible (0% exposure rate) ❌
Verification Commands:

# Confirm MCP extension is active
code --list-extensions | findstr mcp

# Verify configuration files exist
Get-Content .vscode/mcp.json | ConvertFrom-Json

# Test individual MCP servers work
# (Firebase example - replace with your server)
node firebase-mcp-server/dist/stdio.js
Key Indicators of the Issue:
MCP servers start successfully when tested manually
All configurations are syntactically valid
Standard VS Code tools work perfectly in agent
Zero MCP tools appear in agent context regardless of server type
Issue affects ALL MCP server types (Node.js, Python, uvx) equally
Fault Type


=== MCP INTEGRATION FAILURE EVIDENCE ===
Date: 2025-08-17

CONFIGURED MCP SERVERS:
✅ Firebase MCP Server (Node.js)

Location: C:\Users\rruno\Documents\InfinitiCode\BUILD\firebase-mcp-server\dist\stdio.js
Tools: 19 (firebase-auth-, firestore-, functions-*)
Manual Test: SUCCESS - Retrieved 4 users, 7 collections
Agent Context: ABSENT - 0/19 tools visible
✅ ServiceNow MCP Server (Python)

Tools: 3 (servicenow_test, get_incidents, get_servicenow_table_info)
Configuration: Valid with proper instance URL
Agent Context: ABSENT - 0/3 tools visible
✅ Fetch MCP Server (uvx)

Tools: 1 (fetch)
Configuration: Standard MCP implementation
Agent Context: ABSENT - 0/1 tools visible
TOTAL MCP TOOLS CONFIGURED: 23
TOTAL MCP TOOLS IN AGENT CONTEXT: 0

CONTROL GROUP (Standard VS Code Tools):
✅ create_file, read_file, run_in_terminal, etc. - ALL VISIBLE

CONCLUSION: 100% MCP tool absence rate across multiple server types
indicates systemic MCP Extension → Copilot Agent integration failure.

VERIFICATION: Multiple server technologies (Node.js, Python, uvx) with
different configurations all exhibit identical failure pattern.

Contact: rodney.runolfson@gmail.com

title: Allow use of context (#) and command (/) references in chat modes and prompts
body: I feel that if we could reference prompts from chat modes, then - we could put common reusable parts of a mode in a prompt and reference it from multiple modes - it would allow users to also reference the prompts from their own modes - prompts will get updated when extensions are updated to keep them fresh and thereby keep the modes that reference them fresh. (I worry right now about users' custom modes getting stale.) I'd also really like to be able to #fetch from modes and prompts for many of the same reasons, especially because I could fetch a gist or readme from github that would be always up-to-date. I have tried this multiple ways in chat modes, but as far as I can tell it's not supported today. For example the following does not work:

title: Provide easy audit/revise entry point for auto-allow options

labels.name: under-discussion
labels.description: Issue is under discussion for relevance, priority, approach

body:
I also keep hearing users confusion about how to understand and manage the state of auto-allow. It is easy to quickly always-allow and forgetting about it.

Users need a unified access point to audit/reset auto-allowed access:

- MCP commands (session/workspace state, extra command to clear) cc @connor4312 
- Run terminal commands (user/workspace settings) cc @Tyriar 
- File Edits (settings) @connor4312 
- Run tasks/tests (session/workspace state) ?
- Fetch URLs (session/workspace state) ?

Two scenarios:
- Users want to easily manage what they allowed, and add/remove.
- When opening a workspace, a user wants to know what tools the workspace settings auto-allow by default.

title: fix remote branch option for worktree creation
body:
<!-- Thank you for submitting a Pull Request. Please:
* Read our Pull Request guidelines:
  https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/wiki/How-to-Contribute#pull-requests
* Associate an issue with the Pull Request.
* Ensure that the code is up-to-date with the `main` branch.
* Include a description of the proposed changes and how to test them.
-->
Fixes the detached head issue related to creating worktree from remote branch.

- Automatically creates a local branch that tracks remote branch. 
- Handles error when worktree is already used by a local branch tracking the selected remote branch by presenting options to open worktree in current/new window or cancel
- Handles error when local branch name already exists (but worktree does not), by presenting option to create new branch or cancel.

title: a11y fix: updates activity bar inactive foreground icon opacity to improve visibility
body:
Changes ACTIVITY_BAR_FOREGROUND opacity to 0.5 to improve/increase the activity bar inactive icon color contrast against the activity bar background. This improves the contrast for both VSCode Light default theme and VSCode Dark default theme.


* **BEFORE Change** VSCode Light Theme: [FG + opacity] rgba(255, 255, 255, 0.4) on top of [BG] rgb(44, 44, 44) interpreted as #808080 : [BG] rgb(44, 44, 44) | [#2c2c2c](https://critique.corp.google.com/#search/&q=tag:2c2c2c) = 3.53
* **AFTER Change** VSCode Light Theme: [FG + opacity] rgba(255, 255, 255, 0.5) on top of [BG] rgba(44, 44, 44) interpreted as #969696 : [BG] rgba(44, 44, 44) | [#2c2c2c](https://critique.corp.google.com/#search/&q=tag:2c2c2c) = 4.72

* **BEFORE Change** VSCode Dark Theme: [FG + opacity] rgba(255, 255, 255, 0.4) on top of [BG] rgb(51, 51, 51) interpreted as #858585 : [BG] rgb(51, 51, 51) | #333333 = 3.42
* **AFTER Change** VSCode Dark Theme: [FG + opacity] rgba(255, 255, 255, 0.5) on top of [BG] rgb(51, 51, 51) interpreted as #999999 : [BG] rgb(51, 51, 51) | #333333 = 4.43
